com.sri.ai.util.rangeoperation.core

Class RangeOperationsInterpreter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sri.ai.util.rangeoperation.core.RangeOperationsInterpreter

  • @Beta
public class RangeOperationsInterpreter
extends java.lang.Object
    RangeOperationsInterpreter is a facility for easily writing and efficiently computing expressions with nested aggregate operators (for example, \sum_i \prod_j f(i,j)).

    It works by having its apply(Object...) method invoked with a sequence of RangeOperations and a DAEFunction function, iterating over the RangeOperations variables, updating an internal DependencyAwareEnvironment with their current values, and executing, at each iteration, function. The result is a matrix or single value which is the result of the specified operations.

    More precisely, let r1, ..., rn, function be the ranging operations and function received, with a current env environment. If n = 0, the returned value I(r1, ..., rn, function, env) is function(env). If n > 0, the returned value I(r1, ..., rn, function, env) is I(r2, ..., rn, function, env + var = val1) op ... op I(r2, ..., rn, function, env + var = valm), where op, var and val1,...,valm are the aggregate operator, variable, and range of r1, respectively.

    Examples:

    Object result = RangeOperationInterpreter.apply(new Dimension("x", 1, 10), new Dimension("y", 1, 20), xPlusY());
    generates a list of 10 lists, each with 20 elements, containing the sums of the row and column indices.

    Object result = RangeOperationInterpreter.apply(new Dimension("x", 1, 10), new Averaging(1, 20), gaussianWithMeanX());
    generates a list of 10 elements, the x-th element being the average of 20 samples of a Gaussian of mean x. Note that gaussianWithMeanX needs to have its method DAEFunction.isRandom() return true, or it will incorrectly be computed only once per value of x.

    An arbitrary number of range operations can be used, and will be performed in the order they are given. User-defined extensions of DefaultRangeOperation and DAEFunction can be used as well. See the documentation on RangeOperation for details on how to use it.

    An important feature of this framework is automatic caching. Suppose function above only depends on a variable "x". It would then be wasteful to recalculate it for every new value of another variable "y", which may be, for example, only a counter. This does not happen, however, because DependencyAwareEnvironment keeps track of such dependencies automatically.
    IMPORTANT: for this automatic dependency management to occur even for sub-functions inside the DAEFunction, they must be calculated with the DependencyAwareEnvironment.getResultOrRecompute(DAEFunction) method. The function will always be recomputed if DAEFunction.isRandom() returns true, or an ancestor function is random.

    If apply(Object...) receives Strings as arguments, they are assumed to be variables to be put in the environment with the object right after them as value. If an DependencyAwareEnvironment is found, it replaces the default (initially empty) environment, removing previous variable values. Subsequent variables are added to this environment.

    There are a few more tests and examples at com.sri.ai.test.util.rangeoperation.RangeOperationsInterpreterTest

    Author:
    braz
